column1: Gestational diabetes is high blood sugar (glucose) that happens during pregnancy.
But gestational diabetes may: - Cause mild symptoms, such as increased thirst or shakiness.
- Cause a woman to have a larger baby.
Eating healthy can also keep you from gaining too much weight in your pregnancy.
Too much weight gain can increase your risk for gestational diabetes.

Blood sugar that is too high raises the risks for: - Stillbirth - Very small baby (fetal growth restriction) or very large baby (macrosomia) - Difficult labor or cesarean birth (C-section) - Problems with blood sugar or electrolytes in the baby during the first few days after delivery

This will include: - Visits with your provider every week - Ultrasounds that show the size of your baby - A non-stress test that shows whether your baby is doing well If you need insulin or oral medicine to control your blood sugar, you may need to have labor induced 1 or 2 weeks before your due date.
Still, many women with gestational diabetes develop diabetes within 5 to 10 years after giving birth.
